did.unittitle: Indiana University Halls of Residence Libraries records

origination.label: Creator
origination.corpname: Indiana University, Bloomington. Halls of Residence Libraries

did.abstract: The first Halls of Residence Library at Indiana University was created in 1940. It was located in the Men's Residence Center (now the Collins Living-Learning Center). The idea for these libraries came from President Herman B Wells and Halls of Residence Director Alice Nelson, who had visited schools in the east and seen these types of libraries being utilized in university settings. At first administered by the libraries, the Halls of Residence Libraries were transferred to Residential Programs and Services in 2001. This collection includes annual reports, subject files, correspondence and student papers written over the years about the libraries.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open for research. Advance notice required.

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: In 1940, IU President Herman B Wells and Alice Nelson, Director of the Halls of Residence, made trips to examine the dorm libraries at Harvard and Yale. Impressed by what they saw, they decided that the students at Indiana University would benefit from having a similar setup in their residence halls. Once this decision had been reached the next step was to sort out how such an operation would be funded. The problem of funding for the residence hall libraries was solved when it was suggested that the revenue from vending machines be used to fund the new libraries. The revenues from the Coca-Cola and cigarette machines exceeded $250 in the first month and the possibility of the new libraries became a reality.

The first library was in the Men's Residence Center (later called Collins Living-Learning Center). Bookshelves were installed in a room originally used as a lounge. In order to decide what books would be put in the new space Dr. Wells appointed two committees of carefully selected faculty members to assist the student library committee that had already been formed.

As the vending machine profits continued to accumulate, the number of books that the library was able to acquire expanded. The lists included reference materials as well as general reading material. The committees felt that these libraries should include materials to foster the love of reading in general, and should not just serve solely as a source of academic material.

By February 1941, seventy-five books and a set of Encyclopedia Americana had been acquired. The faculty and students gathered to celebrate a grand opening of the library while enjoying tea and witnessing the arrival of the new books. Later that same year the second library was opened in the Women's Residence Center.

WWII put a temporary hold on plans to create new libraries. The MRC was converted to accommodate the armed forces and the library materials were moved to the Women's Residence Center Library. In addition to the move, the vending machine profits began to drop due to the rationing of sugar. The school explored the option of getting milk machines to help make up the deficit in profit, but milk was also in short supply. The libraries managed to survive the war, but their growth during this time was severely hindered.

It wasn't long before the Halls of Residence Committee began pushing to develop the collection in other formats. Band Director Gerald H. Doty was chosen to chair the Halls of Residence Music Committee. At first the committee was charged with the task of selecting music that would have only permanent value, and thus popular music was not be included. However, this strategy did not last long, and popular music was eventually integrated into the collections.

At the close of the war, plans for new residence libraries were put back into motion in conjunction with the building of new residence halls. Dr. Wells made sure that each new hall would be built to include a space for a residence hall library. The University Library also became involved at this time when it decided to help fund the new collection by matching the funds that were acquired by the Student's Art Council. The Main Library not only helped with funding but also with the selection and ordering of materials.

Once involved, the Director of the IU Libraries at the time, Dr. Robert A. Miller, suggested that the libraries should be supervised by trained personnel. This idea was not implemented at the time, which led to the eventual withdrawal of support from the Main Library. At the time the profits from the vending machines were enough to keep the libraries running without the additional funding from the Main Library, but eventually this led to problems.

In 1954, Dr. Alfred C. Kinsey gave 500 records of classical music from his personal collection to the Men's Quad Library. The collection inspired the Residence Hall Libraries to buy circulating phonographs. Over the next few years the system continued to expand under shifting authority. The Halls of Residence turned responsibility of their libraries over to the Graduate School, which later handed the libraries over to the Dean of Students. However, the administrative changes did not benefit the libraries, and it was ultimately decided that a major organizational change was necessary for the continuing survival of the libraries.

In 1959, Samuel Braden, Dean of Undergraduate Development, appointed Barbara Pratt to a part time ten month position as the first professional HRL librarian. Under her direction, inventories were created for the library collections and a union catalog was developed. The five libraries now had combined holdings of about 18,000 volumes. Mrs. Pratt also began looking for opportunities to further expand the libraries and she was soon hired on a full time basis, with a second full-time position added in 1963. That same year the HRL office was relocated to the Main Library. The HRLs continued to grow and by 1968, six new libraries had been established.

The libraries faced another obstacle in 1971. The vending machine sales were suffering greatly due to the increased use of personal refrigerators in the dorm rooms. In order to help the HRL funding, the Assistant Director of the University Libraries, Dr. Cecil Byrd, suggested that they use the fine money from the Main Library. This idea was turned down, but in 1974 the HRL funding and staffing mechanisms were transferred to the IU libraries. The transfer helped the HRL's situation, but it wasn't until the student activity fee was increased in 1978, that the funding issues were finally resolved.

In 2001, the management of the HRLs was transferred from the Libraries to Residential Programs and Services (RPS). At this time RPS decided to develop centers for lending movies and music at Ashton, Briscoe, Forest, McNutt, Read and Wright. These centers would complement the full service libraries found at Apartment Housing, Collins, Eigenmann, Foster, Teter, and Willkie.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into three series: Annual reports; Course materials; Administrative files; and Photographs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The first series in this collection is entitled Annual reports. The records in this series span the years 1961-2001. Each folder includes the records used in compiling the annual report for a given year. Some folders include only financial figures, while others include both the financial figures and full written reports. Some of the folders, the Graduate Association ones in particular, include individual monthly and annual reports for each library within the Halls of Residence Libraries system. This series is arranged chronologically.

The next series, Course materials, spans the years 1962-1980. The bulk of the series is comprised of papers written by students that address different aspects of the Halls of Residence Libraries. The series also includes a folder of SLIS course materials that is made up of in class exercises and some written assignments that center focus on the administration of the HRLs. This series is arranged chronologically.

The Administrative files series is further organized into three sub-series. The first sub-series is Correspondence, 1940-1956, arranged chronologically. The correspondence is primarily concerned with university groups working with the HRL, such as the Graduate Cultural Association, the Graduate Residence Center, and the Men's Residence Center, and the Arts Council. Subject files is the second sub-series and spans 1940-2001. The records in this sub-series document several topics including increasing the student activity fee, funding the libraries, creating library inventories and developing floor plans. There are individual folders for some of the libraries as well as minutes of various committees involved in the creation and maintenance of the libraries. This sub-series is arranged alphabetically by folder title. The last sub-series is Collected history files, arranged alphabetically by folder title. This sub-series includes newspaper clippings, an article on the history of Halls of Residence Libraries up to 1993, and a folder containing papers pertaining to the 40th anniversary of these libraries.

The final series of the collection is Photographs, consisting primarily of a photo album dating from the late 1990s. Photos are of the Residence Halls libraries and staff. There are also a few images that were used in an anniversary display in 1981.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Box 5, consisting of photographs, are housed with the Archives Photographs Collection. Consult the Archives Photographs Curator for further information.

userestrict.head: Usage Restrictions
userestrict.p: Copyrights for records originating with Indiana University administrative units, departments, and other offices are held by the Trustees of Indiana University. For more information, please contact the Indiana University Archives staff.

The Indiana University Archives respects the intellectual property rights of others and does not claim any copyrights for non-university records, materials in the public domain, or materials for which we do not hold a Deed of Gift. Responsibility for the determination of the copyright status of these materials rests with those persons wishing to reuse the materials. Researchers are responsible for securing permission from copyright owners and any other rights holders for any reuse of these materials that extends beyond fair use or other statutory limitations.

Digital reproductions of archival materials from the Indiana University Archives are made available for noncommercial educational and research purposes only. If you are the copyright holder for any of the digitized materials and have questions about its inclusion on our site, please contact the Indiana University Archivist.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Item], Indiana University Halls of Residence Libraries records, Collection C329, Indiana University Archives, Bloomington.
